perturbation.original_text: 19.3. Invoices are payable within 60 days of receipt, with the exception of payments due under Clause 19.2, which shall be payable on the due date or on acceptance of the work, which ever is the later.
perturbation.changed_text: 19.3. Invoices are payable within 30 days of receipt, with the exception of payments due under Clause 19.2, which shall be payable on the due date or on acceptance of the work, which ever is the later.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by changing the invoice payment deadline from 60 days to 30 days. This creates ambiguity about the actual payment terms, leading to potential disputes.

perturbation.original_text: 19.4. Use Fees             The Publishers shall make payments to HealthGate based upon "Use" of             the Content as set forth on the Second Schedule. For the purposes of             this Agreement, "Use" shall mean a retrieval or download by a             Publishers' subscriber of the full-text of an article. There shall             not be any additional use fees or charges for users' browsing of             table of contents or abstracts. Use Fees shall be billed by             HealthGate monthly and all payments are due by cheque by the end of             the following month after the date of the invoice.
perturbation.changed_text:
19.4. Use Fees
The Publishers shall make payments to HealthGate based upon "Use" of the Content as set forth on the Second Schedule. For the purposes of this Agreement, "Use" shall mean a retrieval or download by a Publishers' subscriber of the full-text of an article, or viewing of abstract. There shall be additional use fees or charges for users' browsing of table of contents. Use Fees shall be billed by HealthGate quarterly and all payments are due by electronic transfer within 15 days after the date of the invoice.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text creates a contradiction by defining “Use” to include abstracts, changing the billing cycle from monthly to quarterly, specifying payments due by electronic transfer (instead of cheque), and specifying 15 days as the payment date (instead of the end of the following month). This creates significant financial and operational uncertainty.

perturbation.original_text:
19.5. Interest

            Interest on late payment by either party shall be charged at 2%             above base rate for the time being of Barclays Bank plc in England.             This sub-Clause 19.5 shall survive termination under Clause 9.4.
perturbation.changed_text:
19.5. Interest

            Interest on late payment by either party shall be charged at 5%             above base rate for the time being of Bank of America in USA. No Interest will be charged after 90 days of payment. This sub-Clause 19.5 shall survive termination under Clause 9.4.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by changing the interest rate on late payments, the base rate determination bank, and the fact that no interest will be charged after 90 days of payment. This creates ambiguity about the actual interest to be applied, leading to potential disputes.
